text: Welcome to Exploring Computing.

So in this video,

9, you end up with 16 digits.
Why do we use hexadecimal?

Well, consider this sequence

This particular sequence of bits

for the MIPS CPU, and

is somewhat of a problem.

it's pretty unwieldy.

Here's the problem,
decimal is base 10.

There's a number of
different number systems

that work quite a bit
better with binary

than the decimal
number system does.

One of them is octal, and
the other one is hexadecimal.

And these work much better
because octal is base 8, and 2
to the third power is 8.

And hexadecimal is base 16, and
2 to the fourth power is 16.

And so, there's a
natural relationship

between base 8 and
2, and base 16 and 2

that just isn't there
for base 10 and 2.

And it turns out that because
16 is 2 to the fourth power,

every 4 bits corresponds
to a hexadecimal digit.

So there's a natural
breaking point

where you can look
at every 4 bits

and say, OK, that's a

a hexadecimal digit,

bits at a time, it

If we see 012, that's
